title: S Persei
text:
S Persei is a <a href="red%20supergiant">red supergiant</a> or <a href="hypergiant">hypergiant</a> located near the <a href="Double%20Cluster">Double Cluster</a> in <a href="Perseus%20constellation">Perseus</a>, north of the cluster <a href="NGC%20869">NGC 869</a>. It is a member of the <a href="Perseus%20OB1">Perseus OB1</a> <a href="stellar%20association">association</a> and one of the <a href="List%20of%20largest%20stars">largest known stars</a>. If placed in our solar system, its photospehere would engulf the <a href="orbit">orbit</a> of <a href="Jupiter">Jupiter</a>. It is also a <a href="semiregular%20variable">semiregular variable</a>, a star whose variations are less regular than those of <a href="Mira%20variable">Mira variable</a>s.
Discovery.
S Persei was named by German astronomer <a href="Adalbert%20Krueger">Adalbert Krueger</a> in 1874 after observing that it varied in brightness. It was subsequently listed in major stellar catalogues of that era as <a href="Henry%20Draper%20Catalogue">HD</a> 14528 and <a href="Bonner%20Durchmusterung">BD</a>+57°552.
Variability.
S Persei varies slowly by several <a href="apparent%20magnitude">magnitudes</a>, a factor of over 40 in brightness. It has a main period of somewhat over two years, but shows significant unpredictability. There is a strong variation in the amplitude from around one magnitude to about four magnitudes, and these have been interpreted as <a href="Beat%20%28acoustics%29">beats</a> due to a second period of about 940 days. Other analyses find only the primary period of 813 ± 60 days.
S Persei is classified as a <a href="semiregular%20variable%20star">semiregular variable star</a> of type SRc, indicating that it is a supergiant, and it has one of the largest visual amplitudes of any variable of this type. While the <a href="General%20Catalogue%20of%20Variable%20Stars">General Catalogue of Variable Stars</a> lists it as varying between magnitudes 7.9 and 12.0, it has since been seen fainter.
The <a href="Stellar%20classification">spectral type</a> of S Persei also varies. Typically it is a <a href="red%20supergiant">red supergiant</a> of spectral class M3 or M4, but particularly at deep visual minima it may show a much cooler spectral type of M7 or M8, highly unusual for a supergiant.
Properties.
Many of the visually bright variable stars belong to this class of semiregulars, as these stars are extremely large and luminous, and hence visible across long distances. S Persei has been described as a <a href="hypergiant">hypergiant</a> and has a radius over 700 times the sun's radius (). Its angular diameter has been measured directly and found to be somewhat elliptical. Modelled as a uniform disk, the radius corresponds to .
The temperature has been calculated from the spectrum using a DUSTY model, giving an effective photospheric temperature of 3,500 K and a temperature of 1,000 K for the surrounding dust torus. This is consistent with previous studies, but the derived luminosity from different authors varies from to . Older studies frequently calculated higher luminosities, lower temperatures, and consequently larger values for the radius.
The mass of S Persei is also uncertain, but expected to be around . Mass is being lost at 2.4 to per year, leading to an extensive and complex circumstellar environment of gas and dust.
Location.
S Persei is surrounded by clouds containing water molecules which produce <a href="maser">maser</a> emission. This allows the distance to be measured very accurately using <a href="very%20long%20baseline%20interferometry">very long baseline interferometry</a>, giving an <a href="stellar%20parallax">annual parallax</a> of 0.413 ± 0.017 <a href="milliarcsecond">milliarcsecond</a>s. For comparison the <a href="Gaia%20Data%20Release%202">Gaia Data Release 2</a> parallax is . It lies somewhat further away than the centres of the Double Cluster <a href="open%20cluster">open cluster</a>s, but definitely within the Per OB1 association and the <a href="Perseus%20Arm">Perseus Arm</a> of the galaxy.
S Persei is a double star. The red supergiant has an A0 11th magnitude companion at 69". There are also several other 8th to 10th magnitude stars within half a degree of S Persei.
